question.text: How many ATPs are produced when <math><mn>12</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math> pass through <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></math> - <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></math> particle?

solution.text: The energy released during the electron system is utilized in synthesizing ATP with the help of the ATP synthase enzyme (complex V). This complex consists of two major components <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></math> and <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></math>. For each ATP produced, <math><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></math> passes through <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></math> from the intermembrane space to the matrix down the electrochemical proton gradient. Hence, accordingly, if 12 H+ ions pass then 6 ATP is produced.
